outputs.output_descr: Various level governments and communities in project area  will better conserve bamboo forest. Guidelines and manuals on  conservation of natural bamboo forests developed and disseminated. Policies to encourage the prioritization of bamboo conservation

Improved biodiversity conservation (BDC) in HHRB via integration of biodiversity conservation into development plans of local governments and the relevant sector agencies and the piloting of "Authorized Management" of biodiversity resources

1. New Strategies, policies and guidelines on biodiversity conservation at both national and provincial level respectively are approved and published by 2009.
2. CBDSC and its secretariat in SEPA are strengthened with improved institutional setup by 2009 so as to supervise all biodiversity programs in China.
3. Biodiversity conservation is integrated into key relevant policies and into some sectoral development plans at both national and provincial level by 2009.
4. The public (in representative areas, including field projects) has an increased understanding of the concept of biodiversity by 2009. 
5. Senior national and provincial (in field project areas) decision makers in relevant sectors routinely consider biodiversity in their decisions by 2010.
6. A series of innovative methods for biodiversity management are tested in selected ecosystems and disseminated by 2010.
7. Monitoring systems in field project areas can regularly indicate impact on ecosystems, key species and other biodiversity indices by 2010
8. Nineteen biodiversity field projects at provincial and local levels representing successful international and national partnerships have been implemented according to Guidelines and Grant Agreement.

Strengthening the integration of biodiversity assessment into strategic environmental assessment of mining development plan and tourism development plan to promote the consideration of biodiversity conservation in the planning stage of the macro-plans
A new Protected Area's model for China is developed and implemented in two locations combining biodiversity conservation with local socio-economic development
Different stakeholders from different sectors and government levels in China support integrated management of mountain wetlands and their biodiversity

Degradation of medicinal plant populations and key habitats mitigated and local medicinal plant harvester's livelihoods improved in key landscapes of the Upper Yangtze ecoregion through development of a strategic model based on innovative ecosystem management methods linked to incentive based approaches to biodiversity conservation and sustainable development in China.

With support from local agricultural authorities, institutions and private enterprises, farmers implement biodiversity friendly farming practices in selected mountain areas of southern China in a sustainable way.
Strengthened biodiversity conservation and sustainablbe management on the Hulunbeir grasslands
Rural communities maintain and enhance diverse agro-ecosystems
